Title:
Four new species of Aleurodiscus s.l. (Russulales,
Basidiomycota) from China
Keywords:
acanthophyses; corticioid fungi; Stereaceae; taxonomy;
wood-inhabiting fungi
Abstract:
Four new species of Aleurodiscus s.l. with corticioid
basidiocarps are described and illustrated from China based on
morphological evidence and phylogenetic analyses of ITS and nrLSU
sequence data. Aleurodiscus bambusinus was collected from Jiangxi
Province, southern China on bamboo and is distinct by having a compact
texture, simple-septate generative hyphae, numerous acanthophyses,
basidia with a acanthophysoid appendage and smooth spores. Aleurodiscus
changbaiensis was collected from Jilin Province, northeastern China on
angiosperm wood and is distinct by having clamped generative hyphae,
numerous acanthophyses and small smooth basidiospores. Aleurodiscus
isabellinus was collected from Yunnan Province, southwestern China on
both bamboo and angiosperm wood and is distinct by having yellow to
yellowish brown basidiocarps and acanthophyses, simple septate
generative hyphae and smooth basidiospores. Aleurodiscus subroseus was
collected from Guangxi Autonomus Region, southern China on angiosperm
wood and is distinct by having pinkish basidiocarps when fresh, clamped
generative hyphae and echinulate basidiospores. In the phylogenetic
tree, A. bambusinus, A. changbaiensis and A. isabellinus were nested
within the A. cerussatus group, whilst A. subroseus formed a lineage
sister to A. wakefieldiae. An identification key to 27 species in China
is provided.
